snippet: A small group of victors in House and Senate races this week speak fluidly and abstractly about religion, when they talk about it at all.
abstract: Mark Oppenheimer Beliefs column notes small group of victors in the House and Senate elections succeeded despite their uncommon religious affiliations; contends this was made possible because they learned to discuss their faith, or lack of it, in fluid and abstract terms that resemble a growing portion of voters who do not adhere to any specific religious tradition.
lead_paragraph: A small group of victors in House and Senate races this week speak fluidly and abstractly about religion, when they talk about it at all.

headline.print_headline: Politicians Who Reject Labels Based on Religion
headline.seo: Politicians Who Speak of Religion in Unaccustomed Ways
headline.main: Politicians Who Reject Labels Based on Religion

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)
